div.p:
BooksPicker grew out of our own frustrations as students buying books. The COOP's prices were absurdly high, and the process of buying books elsewhere was time-consuming and tedious, especially when we wanted to compare offers between online merchants and students.
But above all we did not like the fact that we could not just enter the classes we were taking and based on that find the books we needed. We thought that this should be an easy task, since The COOP had all the information, but we were wrong. We found out that The COOP was unwilling to share the information with anyone (including MIT). Apparently they obtain the information directly from the faculty, without going through an in-house MIT channel.
We thought this situation was unacceptable, so we decided to fight for the freedom of the information (and this is why we are pirates). We wrote an article on The Tech and started a discussion with many groups at MIT, including faculty, IS&T, and MIT Libraries. Our efforts and the Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2008, which requires all educational institutions provide such textbook information by June 2010, served as catalysts for MIT to enhance its Online Textbook Information (OTI) system. As such, MIT now makes book information available to anyone, including services such as the course catalog and Stellar. The information provided by OTI is still incomplete, but we are happy that things are moving in the right direction. And even though our main fight is over, we are still here to serve you and provide you with the best experience for buying and selling your textbooks.
BooksPicker was built by a group of three MIT students (Jonathan Goldberg, Sinchan Banerjee, and Rodrigo Ipince) with the advice of Professor David Karger.
We love feedback. If you have some, send it to us at bookspicker at mit.edu.
